pages.name: Engage
pages.introText:
Velocity

The dashboard instrument to the right, called a speedometer, tells us how fast a car is moving.

The eddy-current speedometer was patented in 1902 by Otto Shultz. Through a complex interaction of wheels, cables, gears, magnets, forces, and electric currents, the speedometer's needle points to a car's current speed.

(You can read more about the topic by researching "eddy-current speedometer.")

pages.name: Predict With Numbers
pages.introText:
Velocity

Let's start by predicting how fast you normally walk.

Walk approximately 4 meters at your normal walking pace.

pages.name: Predict With Graph (Normal)
pages.introText:
Velocity

Keeping your prediction in mind, draw a graph showing your position over time as you walked from 0 to 4 meters.

pages.name: Predict With Graph (Slow)
pages.introText:
Velocity

The top graph shows your predicted normal walking pace.

On the bottom graph, predict what slow, steady motion would look like from 0 to 4 meters.

pages.name: Normal vs Slow (Predictions)
pages.introText:
Velocity

The top graph shows your predicted normal walking pace. The bottom graph shows your predicted slow walking pace.

What do you observe about your predictions?

pages.name: Collect Data (Normal)
pages.introText:
Velocity

You will test your prediction by walking at a normal, steady pace along a straight 4-meter path while using a motion sensor.

Place the sensor at the 0-meter mark.

Stand near the sensor. When you are ready, have your partner click Start to record the data for your movements.

Walk on the path at a normal, steady pace.

Click Reset to try a different normal, steady pace.

pages.name: Collect Data (Slow)
pages.introText:
Velocity

Now you will try walking at a slow, steady pace.

Place the sensor at the 0-meter mark.

Stand near the sensor. When you are ready, have your partner click Start to record the data for your movements.

Walk on the path at a slow, steady pace.

pages.name: Actual vs. Prediction (Normal)
pages.introText:
Velocity

On the top is your predicted position-time graph for normal, steady motion. Below is your actual position-time graph for normal, steady motion.

pages.name: Actual vs. Prediction (Slow)
pages.introText:
Velocity

On the top is your predicted position-time graph for slow, steady motion. Below is your actual position-time graph for slow, steady motion.

pages.name: Normal vs Slow (Actual)
pages.introText:
Velocity

Here is the data you just collected for normal and slow, steady motion.

pages.name: Instantaneous Speed
pages.introText:
Velocity

Suppose you collected some actual position-time data while walking from 0 to 15 meters and displayed your data to the right. Let's find out how fast you walked during different time intervals.

First you will pick two points that are next to each other and find the speed between those points. This calculation will be close to your instantaneous speed.

pages.name: Instantaneous Speed II
pages.introText:
Velocity

Now you will pick another set of points that are next to each other and find the speed between those points.

pages.name: Instantaneous Speed III
pages.introText:
Velocity

Was your speed during the two different time intervals the same? If not, during which interval were you going faster? Explain how you know.

pages.name: Average Speed
pages.introText:
Velocity

To find the average speed for the entire trip, you will use the start and end points of the whole trip.

pages.name: Analyze/Conclusion
pages.introText:
Velocity

In this activity, you predicted and confirmed different steady speeds while walking along a straight path.

steps.beforeText: Describe another way that you can tell how fast you are moving.
About how many seconds did it take?

Based on your estimate, what is your average speed in meters per second?

Remember that average speed = total distance/total time.

For forward motion, position should increase with time.

Do your lines point in an upward direction?

For steady motion, your position should increase at a constant rate.

Is your prediction for steady motion a straight line?

Compare the steepness of your two graphs.

In which graph is position always greater at a given time?
Based on your data, how long did it take you to walk 4 meters at your normal pace?
If it took you [TBD] seconds to walk 4 meters, then you were walking at a rate of [TBD] meters per second.
Did your prediction graph of normal, steady motion match the actual data? Explain.
Did your prediction graph of slow, steady motion match the actual data? Explain.
How does normal, steady motion differ from slow, steady motion on a position-time graph?
Click a point, any point.
Click a point next to the first one.
Here is a line through the two points.
Here is a “rise” arrow.
Here is a “run” arrow.
What is the speed between the two points?
Click a point, any point.
Click a point next to the first one.
Here is a line through the two points.
Here is a “rise” arrow.
Here is a “run” arrow.
What is the speed between the two points?
Click the point that represents the start of the trip.
Click that represents the end of the trip.

Here is a line through the two points.

What was your average speed during the whole trip?
steps.afterText: Hint: what were your total distance and your total time?

steps.beforeText: Which of the lines in the accompanying graph indicates the fastest speed? Which indicates the slowest? Explain how you know.
What is the difference between instantaneous speed and average speed?
How can a graph convey speed?
